unnormalised: Folks, ever wondered what time it is for your cousin studying in the US while you're sipping chai in India? Or maybe you're prepone-ing that Zoom meeting with the London office? It's all about time zones, yaar!
normalised: Folks, ever wondered what time it is for your cousin studying in the U-S while you're sipping chai in India? Or maybe you're preponing that Zoom meeting with the London office? It's all about time zones, yaar!

unnormalised: So, India follows Indian Standard Time, or IST, which is GMT+5:30. That means we're always 5 and a half hours ahead of Greenwich Mean Time. Makes planning international calls a bit of a headache, doesn't it?
normalised: So, India follows Indian Standard Time, or I-S-T, which is G-M-T plus five hours and thirty minutes. That means we're always five and a half hours ahead of Greenwich Mean Time. Makes planning international calls a bit of a headache, doesn't it?

unnormalised: Now, the US is a whole different ballgame. They have several time zones, like Eastern Time (ET) which is GMT-5, Central Time (CT) at GMT-6, Mountain Time (MT) at GMT-7, and Pacific Time (PT) at GMT-8. So, figuring out the difference between IST and, say, PST can get confusing real quick. Imagine coordinating a 9:00 AM PST conference call when you're in Mumbai!
normalised: Now, the U-S is a whole different ballgame. They have several time zones, like Eastern Time (E-T) which is G-M-T minus five, Central Time (C-T) at G-M-T minus six, Mountain Time (M-T) at G-M-T minus seven, and Pacific Time (P-T) at G-M-T minus eight. So, figuring out the difference between I-S-T and, say, P-S-T can get confusing real quick. Imagine coordinating a nine zero zero A-M P-S-T conference call when you're in Mumbai!

unnormalised: And let's not forget Europe! London's on GMT during standard time and GMT+1 during daylight saving time (BST). So, a 2:00 PM meeting in London is already 6:30 PM in India. Time flies, literally!
normalised: And let's not forget Europe! London's on G-M-T during standard time and G-M-T plus one during daylight saving time (B-S-T). So, a two zero zero P-M meeting in London is already six thirty P-M in India. Time flies, literally!

unnormalised: Australia is even more complicated. Sydney's on Australian Eastern Standard Time (AEST), which is GMT+10. During daylight saving, it's AEDT, which is GMT+11. That's a whopping 5:30 hrs offset!
normalised: Australia is even more complicated. Sydney's on Australian Eastern Standard Time (A-E-S-T), which is G-M-T plus ten. During daylight saving, it's A-E-D-T, which is G-M-T plus eleven. That's a whopping five hours and thirty minutes offset!

unnormalised: Just a heads up, daylight saving time (DST) also throws another wrench in the works. Some countries advance their clocks by an hour during the summer months, which changes the time difference. So remember to double-check those conversions around March/April and September/October!
normalised: Just a heads up, daylight saving time (D-S-T) also throws another wrench in the works. Some countries advance their clocks by an hour during the summer months, which changes the time difference. So remember to double-check those conversions around March slash April and September slash October!

unnormalised: Tools like World Time Buddy and even a simple Google search can be lifesavers for figuring out time zone conversions. Trust me, your international colleagues will thank you for not scheduling that meeting at 3:00 AM their time!
normalised: Tools like World Time Buddy and even a simple Google search can be lifesavers for figuring out time zone conversions. Trust me, your international colleagues will thank you for not scheduling that meeting at three zero zero A-M their time!

unnormalised: So next time you're planning an international call or just curious about what time it is in another part of the world, remember these time zones and do a quick check! It'll save you from embarrassing mix-ups and keep everyone happy. Keep clock-watching, my friends!
